qas.question: What is the name for the rules issued by the heads of the Church?
In what type of religion are canon laws applicable?
Which institutions make up the Catholic Church?

answers.text: Latin Church and Eastern Catholic Churches

qas.question: What body was first responsible for creating canon?
What does canon law consist of?
What is the name of rules made by lay people of the church?
What church is made up of the Latin and Western Catholic churches
All religions are governed by what rules?
What was originally adopted by the Pope?

plausible_answers.text: the Eastern and Oriental Orthodox churches, and the individual national churches within the Anglican Communion

qas.question: Throughout what three bodies is canon law interpreted the same way?

context: <a0_0><b5_0><b7_0><b8_0>Canon law<b8_0/><b7_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> is the body of laws and regulations made by ecclesiastical authority (Church leadership), for the government of a <a1_0>Christian<a1_0/> organization or church and its members. It is the internal ecclesiastical law governing the <b6_0>Catholic Church<b6_0/> (both <a2_0>Latin Church and Eastern Catholic Churches<a2_0/>), <b9_0>the Eastern and Oriental Orthodox churches, and the individual national churches within the Anglican Communion<b9_0/>. The way that such church law is legislated, interpreted and at times adjudicated varies widely among these three bodies of churches. In all three traditions, a canon was originally a rule adopted by a <a3_0>church council<a3_0/>; these <a4_0>canons<a4_0/> formed the foundation of canon law.
